posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
We have an orange pi 5 on our robot. The USB ports have 1 by 1 been failing. Specifically the ports appear to not be delivering power to devices plugged in. We had a camera plugged in at some point while practicing the camera failed. moving it to another port solved the issue and that happened again. Now all the ports are busted and we can’t figure out why. Or what is causing it. It is not a software issue (nothing with photonvision). They tried accessing the PI though SSH ( @Ian_McTavish ) can tell you more about that.

People keep pointing to power supply but unless our power supply is causing the USB ports on the orange pi to physical stop supplying power forever then that seems unlikely.

We have a spare pi but would prefer not to break it as well. At the same time we are upgrading the power supply to the Pololu - 5V, 5.5A Step-Down Voltage Regulator D36V50F5

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: How are your camera and Opi5 mounted? Is anything shorting the power pins somehow?

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
They are in individual cases printed in pla. I haven’t seen any evidence of the pins being able to be shorted.

Also we are using a fan but only just received the heatsinks. It doesn’t seem to get particularly hot yet.

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked: Every time this happens we are worried the camera breaks but we plug the camera into a computer and it works fine. We also tried plugging a mouse to see if the laser turns on but it doesn’t get any power.

posts.name: Clare R Greenlaw Jr
posts.cooked: Good day! We had the same thing and it cost us much of our driver practice time near our first event. It was all static. Yes, static. The immediate cure was Bounce static guard spray wiped all over the robot. Your com lines need to be cat 7 or 8, where they are shielded. Your data portions of the coms lines are likely grabbing the static charge and are not protected to handle any real voltage. So they blow every time a random discharge happens. Rty the spray and I bet it will allow you to run for at least 45 minutes without any evidence of an issue…Longer, the more you keep coating.

posts.name: Clare R Greenlaw Jr
posts.cooked: PS. We also used the voltage regulator as well to no effect b/c the charge enters after the PDH to regulator connections.

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
We ended up switching to limelight for now. We might investigate it after competition but not now. One idea we had that appears to be legal is grounding the frame to a negative port in the PDH . Would this keep static from damaging components?

This Grounding Strap has 470Ω resistor to prevent high-current discharges and safely ground a robot's metal frame. The ring terminal should be attached to a metal surface using a nut and bolt while the XT30 end is plugged into a free port.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Smtopps:

One idea we had that appears to be legal is grounding the frame to a negative port in the PDH .

The robot frame?  That is not legal, see R611:

All wiring and electrical devices shall be electrically isolated from the ROBOT frame.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: That grounding strap is for FTC , not FRC .

We had a similar issue with static disabling us in our practice setup, and the solution turned out to be dragging some exposed copper wire down behind the bumpers and attached to our frame. It solved it and we confirmed that when we put it back on incorrectly after bumper mounting work and immediately shorted out. Also Ferrites helped.

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked:
Just to be sure I got this right - you have a copper wire that touches and drags across the carpet?

We are having random robot disables on our practice field - they only happen if the robot is being driven,.

I’m desperate enough to try a ground wire - just want to make sure I’ve got the concept right.

posts.name: Haluk A. I.
posts.cooked: we had a similar problem, but restarting photonvision somehow fixed it. its a problem when it happens during a match tho.

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: We usually have a short loop of bead chain around the frame so that it just touches the carpet. Same idea.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: I’m all for using what is on hand and I like your chain but for those who demand the “best” (expensive) there are Official Copper Grounding Brushes

link_counts.title: Shaft Grounding Brushes | Earthing Brushes in Bulk

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: I had no idea such a thing even existed!

What did you find out? Having the same thing happening here on our test setup. Only port that works is the vertical one on the PI 5, the two stacked ones are no go. The vertical one and the white bottom one work with a keyboard connected to monitor, but the blue top one doesn’t. Maybe shorted out somehow. Did you ever get yours back

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked:
We didn’t really solve the issue for sure but we think it was static. The camera was mounted near our shooter and the note sliding against some polycarbonate was creating quite a bit of static. The camera was mounted to the same piece of polycarbonate and somehow the static was jumping through the usb of the camera and frying whatever USB port was connected at the time.

We also realized it was only happening after long practice sessions. Particularly where we didn’t really do much driving and just took a bunch of shoots. Short practice would not have issues since you would touch the robot and ground it keeping too much static buildup. We switched to limelight for both the issue above and some software things. The static ended up killing a USB port on a 2+ as well. Since that we added a chain for grounding and upgraded to 3 and 3g and haven’t had any issues since. I’m not completely sure but when I was emailing with limelight about the issue it sounded like the 3 had better protection on the USB port to prevent that issue.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Sounds like dragging a chain is the best idea. You can see why inexpensive computers don’t have great ESD protection on the USB ports. This USB isolator costs much more than the computer just to protect four high-speed USB ports. Cheaper ($30-$50) ones available for one, low-speed port but some don’t claim ESD protection so beware.

If you want just ESD protection there are cheaper alternatives 4 Port USB 3.2 Gen 1 Type-C Hub w/ ESD Surge Protection - Coolgear
